rComments: Jin is the quintessential example professor of why tenure is ruining higher education. He does not care about teaching. He doesn't care about his research anymore. A total jackass that only wants prestige, something he will never attain if he cannot be  influential while teaching chemistry. If you actually want to learn quantum, don't take it w/Jin

Jin often does not teach the material, assumes you have learned quantum physics in high school, and is a very confusing lecturer. However, if you go to MSI/discussion, you can get an A pretty easily, since he typically has fairly easy tests and a great curve that is the same for every test (80% is an A).

By far the worst chem professor I've ever had. Jin does not explain anything well and I'm scared to ask him questions because he'll always respond by yelling. The material itself is easy if you learn from the book. If you go to his lectures you will leave the class being more confused than ever. HE DOES NOT GIVE ANY REVIEW SHEETS OR PRACTICE EXAMS.

Jin is a terrible professor. If you ask questions, prepare for him to tell you that he's gone over it already. He also expects you to know physics despite that not being a pre-req for the class. His lectures are hard to follow so read the book. The homework is easy but you never know what to expect from Zhang. Avoid him for Chem 1B.

Jin assigns archaic and difficult homework that has no relevance to exams. Also, he is often rude to students if they ask a question he doesn't approve of, which is unprofessional and petty. Fortunately his exams are fair and he is a generous grader. He usually explains concepts clearly. His major issue is his attitude when answering questions.
Very helpful. His lectures were not always useful, but he was always available if I needed help with concepts. Great professor overall!

Jin is an authority in the field of Chemistry and if you choose to take his course you should respect him as such. With that said, chemistry is NOT an easy subject and you should NOT expect to get an A by studying a few days before exams. YOU NEED to keep up with the class, UNDERSTAND the homework, and ASK QUESTIONS at office hours = A.

When it comes to Chemistry, Jin is the type of teacher that knows the material fully. However, his lectures aren't really that helpful since it's just based on the txtbook. Just make sure to follow the txtbook/lecture closely to pass.
Jin is very knowledgable about Chemistry but lectures don't really help. Rely on the book and actually work out the homework  and you will pass for sure. Very generous curve!
HORRIBLE. Can't understand what he says. He does not completely finish his example problems. He just gives up ad says "solve for x" You should wait for another teacher to take Chem 1A.

This is the kind of teacher who's lower div classes are awful and his upper divs are ok. Had Chem 1B with him and have never met a more impatient or intolerant professor. Much more focused on his research than teaching a bunch of freshman, and he was incredibly unapproachable and rude to students asking for help. Doesn't answer Q's in emails EVER.

Took Chem 1A in the summer with him, and it was hard because of all the material being covered. Although he has the accent, go to his office hours and he will help you. just practice problems in the book and from lectures, it will help. Go to the TA as well. Awesome teacher, great personality :)

Beware of Jin Zhang.  If you take him, you might not understand him because of his accent.  Also, if you attend office hours, he will be disrespectful.  He will treat you as if you do not need help.  Also, his final was difficult.  The average for the final was about 60%.  I barely passed his class with a C.  Do not take this guy for Chem class.

His lectures were him reading and writing examples straight out of the book. There is no point in going to lecture. It would be better if you just read the book. Not too bad tests since they were multiple choice. If you ask a question in class he will act like you're stupid. He should only be teacher upper div classes because he's too smart

Jin, is an extremely nice and intelligent person, however, he expects chem 1A students to know more that we actually do... At times his lectures could be a bit confusing...Make sure to read the book, and look at the examples in the book because his lectures are based 100% off the book.. He goes rlly quickly through examples and chapters so just make sure to keep up. And get any extra possible help for this class... Tutors, Msi, anything that's available. it will help, trust me

Chem 1a is a class that requires a lot of effort no matter which teacher you take the class with. He is very straight forward and follows the book very closely. His tests are strongly based off the hw, so if you understand the concepts in the HW you will do great in the class. Going to section for this class is a Must to do well.

Teacher has the worst possible chinese accent. super hard to understand and gets frustrated very easily. Made my chemistry experience very difficult. He is lenient on homework but he cannot teach at all. be prepared to self teach or to suffer,

He made Chem 1A a nightmare for me. If you can understand a word he is saying (he has a very thick accent), you might do alright. But he talks a lot and has very minimal notes (in unreadable handwriting). He teaches  mostly about theory and expects you to teach yourself how to do the problems. I'm hoping Chem 1B is a better experience.

He is a very smart guy and usually teaches updivision chem classes, but when he taught this class he was awful.  I think it is due to the fact that the material is so easy to him, that it is easy for him to skip over important small details that do make a difference.  Needless to say, he doesn't teach well at all.
Absolutely horrible. He doesn't teach at all.  During class he skips calculations and tells you they are in the book.  Almost impossible. Hated his class.

Very smart guy.Seems like a very nice person. Expects us to know what he is teaching us. Will start an example problem, then tell us we already know how to do it and to do it as a practice at home. Very difficult to understand when talking about chemistry related things. Uses an iPad to write notes with- illegible.

Very organized and fair. Lets you know what is expected of you and is not tricky. Do the homework, problems on exams often come straight from it. Friendly and helpful in office hours. Attend lectures. Often puts up sample exam style practice problems. Excellent teacher. Enthusiastic, knowledgable and does want students to succeed.

One of the best professors I've had. Clearly outlines expectations of class. His hyper-organized personality made lectures easy to follow and well defined. Tests are very straight forward. Doesn't bog you down in uneccesary math; focuses on concepts and basic understanding. Helpful in office hours and very fair.
One of the best profs I had at UCSC. Very clear on what he wants you to know, and makes sure you understand the topic. Easy to approach and very helpful.

I just want to say to those people who gave the professor a bad rating...it's not that he doesn't speak clearly, it's because you guys ARE NOT trying!!! He is a wonderful professor and very understanding. He explains to all his students that if you do not understand him, he will  repeat himself. His exams ARE NOT difficult at all!

I took this course during the summer and it could just be that i'm from another school, but i thought he was by far the best professor i'd ever had. he wrote everything he said on the board, clearly, following the text and repeated what he thought was important. i thought that if you put the work in, which he outlined, it was easy to do well.
one time, he said "elardon" but really it was "electron." he's pretty funny, though, and always cracking jokes that go over everyone's heads until 5 minutes later.

he is not that good. yea... given he is very intelligent, as a teacher ... man. what can I say? he's very hard to understand and even if you pass the class, chances are you're STILL going to get a horrible eval.
Thick accent keeps from students understanding his lectures completely. Overall a very thorough professor.
Fairly hard for an introductory chemistry class. He's very eccentric and has a thick accent.
A fantastic teacher.  You have to do a lot of work, but his tests are fair, and he explains everything well.  Showing up to class is a must.
Jin is awesome, the best teache I've ever had, hands down.  He is so clear, and makes chemistry really interesting (hard to do).  I would reccommend him to anyone.
Great prof, hilarious, awesome lectures, tests are challenging but fair.
No Comments
